recommendations: Remove and destroy severely infected leaves; sterilize tools between plants
Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or myclobutanil at first sign of pustules

Apply neem oil biweekly as organic preventative after infection subsides
Address yellowing leaves immediately with balanced micronutrient supplement
Treat leaning/stalk damage by hilling soil around bases for support
Improve pollination by hand-shaking tassels if kernel development is uneven
Combat drought stress with deep watering and seaweed extract application
Remove pest-damaged sections promptly; apply BT spray for caterpillar control

Apply copper fungicide or Bacillus subtilis bioweekly, covering both leaf surfaces
Reduce watering frequency; allow soil surface to dry between irrigations
Stake plants to improve airflow and reduce humidity around foliage
Supplement with seaweed extract to strengthen plant defenses
Destroy all infected plants immediately (do not compost); report outbreaks if required
Apply mandipropamid or fluazinam fungicides at first sign of water-soaked lesions
Stop overhead watering completely; use soaker hoses for ground-level irrigation
Harvest tubers early if blight appears; cure in dry, dark location for 3 weeks
Solarize soil after harvest by tilling and covering with clear plastic for 6 weeks
Address leafhopper damage with pyrethrin spray; remove curled leaves
Treat sun-scalded tubers by adding thicker mulch layer over hills
Correct hollow heart disorder with consistent boron-calcium supplementation
Revive heat-stressed plants with afternoon shade cloth and increased watering
Control vole damage with underground mesh barriers around planting area
Remove infected leaves showing target spots; sterilize pruners between cuts
Spray chlorothalonil or copper fungicide weekly during humid weather
Apply baking soda solution (1 tbsp/gal water + soap) as organic alternative
Reduce nitrogen fertilization to limit succulent growth susceptible to infection
Improve root function with mycorrhizal inoculant to compensate for leaf loss
Destroy entire plants at first sign of greasy lesions or white mold (do not compost)
Spray cymoxanil or famoxadone+cymoxanil mixtures within 24 hours of detection
Harvest mature green fruits immediately; disinfect with warm water bath
Remove all nearby volunteer tomatoes and potatoes within 200 feet
Apply biofungicides containing Trichoderma harzianum to protect new growth
Prune lesions with sterilized shears; disinfect tools after each plant
Spray copper-mancozeb combination products every 5-7 days during outbreaks
Reduce leaf wetness by improving airflow and watering only at soil level
Apply acibenzolar-S-methyl to activate systemic resistance pathways
Supplement with silicon to strengthen epidermal cells against invasion

Apply chlorothalonil or difenoconazole sprays covering leaf undersides

Reduce relative humidity using fans and dehumidifiers below 80%
Treat with potassium bicarbonate fungicide (4 tsp/gal) every 10 days
Remove spotted leaves immediately; destroy all fallen debris
Spray mancozeb or copper hydroxide weekly during wet periods
Improve air circulation with strategic pruning of inner branches
Apply hydrogen peroxide solution (1 tsp 35% food grade per cup water)
Supplement with silicon to increase leaf cuticle resistance
Prune leaves showing concentric rings; avoid excessive defoliation
Rotate azoxystrobin and difenoconazole applications every 7 days
Reduce canopy density by removing non-fruiting branches
Apply neem oil + potassium bicarbonate mixtures as organic option
Boost plant immunity with salicylic acid root drenches
Treat transplant shock with kelp extract and reduced sun exposure
Correct blossom-end rot with calcium nitrate foliar sprays
Revive wilted plants with deep root watering and temporary shading

Manage root-knot nematodes with marigold interplanting
